[![A black circle outlined in hazy streaks of white emanating from the circle
to the edges of the image all on a solid black
background](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Solar_eclipse_22_July_2009_taken_by_Lutfar_Rahman_Nirjhar_from_Bangladesh.jpg/200px-
Solar_eclipse_22_July_2009_taken_by_Lutfar_Rahman_Nirjhar_from_Bangladesh.jpg)](/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_22_July_2009_taken_by_Lutfar_Rahman_Nirjhar_from_Bangladesh.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_22_July_2009_taken_by_Lutfar_Rahman_Nirjhar_from_Bangladesh.jpg
"Enlarge")

Total [solar eclipse of July 22, 2009](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_22,_2009
"Solar eclipse of July 22, 2009"), from [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh
"Bangladesh").

During the 21st century, there will be 224 [solar
eclipses](/wiki/Solar_eclipse "Solar eclipse") of which 77 will be partial, 72
will be annular, 68 will be total and 7 will be hybrids between total and
annular eclipses. Of these, two annular and one total eclipse will be non-
central,[1] in the sense that the very center (axis) of the moon's shadow will
miss the earth (for more information see [gamma](/wiki/Gamma_\(eclipse\)
"Gamma \(eclipse\)")).[2] In the 21st century the greatest number of eclipses
in one year is four, in 2011, 2029, 2047, 2065, 2076, and 2094. The
predictions given here are by [Fred Espenak](/wiki/Fred_Espenak "Fred
Espenak") of [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA")'s [Goddard Space Flight
Center](/wiki/Goddard_Space_Flight_Center "Goddard Space Flight Center").[1]

At this point, the longest duration in which the moon completely covered the
sun, known as [totality](/wiki/Solar_eclipse#Totality "Solar eclipse"), was
during the [solar eclipse of July 22,
2009](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_22,_2009 "Solar eclipse of July 22, 2009").
This total solar eclipse had a maximum duration of 6 minutes and 39 seconds.
The longest possible duration of a total solar eclipse is 7 minutes and 32
seconds. The longest annular solar eclipse of the 21st century took place on
[January 15, 2010](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_January_15,_2010 "Solar eclipse of
January 15, 2010"), with a duration of 11 minutes and 8 seconds. The maximum
possible duration is 12 minutes and 29 seconds. The eclipse of [May 20,
2050](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_May_20,_2050 "Solar eclipse of May 20, 2050"),
will be the second hybrid eclipse in the span of less than one year, the first
one being on [November 25, 2049](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_November_25,_2049
"Solar eclipse of November 25, 2049").[a]

The next solar eclipse (Partial) will occur on [February 15,
2018](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_February_15,_2018 "Solar eclipse of February 15,
2018"); the last solar eclipse (Total) occurred on [August 21,
2017](/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_August_21,_2017 "Solar eclipse of August 21,
2017").

The table contains the date and time of the greatest eclipse (in [dynamical
time](/wiki/Dynamical_time "Dynamical time"), which in this case is the time
when the axis of the Moon's shadow cone passes closest to the centre of Earth;
this is in [Universal Time](/wiki/Universal_Time "Universal Time")). The
number of the [saros series](/wiki/Saros_\(astronomy\) "Saros \(astronomy\)")
that the eclipse belongs to is given, followed by the [magnitude of the
eclipse](/wiki/Magnitude_of_eclipse "Magnitude of eclipse") (the fraction of
the Sun's diameter obscured by the Moon) and the type of the eclipse (either
total, annular, partial or hybrid). For total and annular eclipses, the
duration of the eclipse is given, as well as the location of the greatest
eclipse (the point of maximum eclipse) and the path width of the total or
annular eclipse. The geographical areas from which the eclipse can be seen are
listed.[3]
